reasoning:
Centrality: The critique targets the essay’s VNM/cardinalization setup and the 0.5/0.9 thresholds used to define “mostly-great/eutopia” and to classify views as “fussy/easygoing,” which is central to Section 3’s systematic argument and to some headline claims about “most plausible moral views.” But the essay also offers substantial non-VNM, informal support (fragility/product-of-factors, historical moral catastrophe examples), so refuting the VNM framework wouldn’t fully collapse the overall “no easy eutopia” conclusion.

Strength: The critique shows a real limitation: many plausible moral views with lexical constraints, incomparability, or non-expected-value structure won’t satisfy VNM completeness/independence, making the quantitative thresholds and some probability/gamble comparisons inapplicable. However, the essay explicitly acknowledges that not all moral views fit (it restricts the technical section to complete/VNM-satisfying views and notes some views can’t be represented), so calling it “window-dressing” overreaches. The best version of the objection is: the paper later generalizes from this restricted class to “most plausible views,” and that generalization is under-supported. Still, this only partially undermines the paper because (i) many influential moral theories do accept VNM-style representation for prospects, and (ii) the nontechnical sections can be run without exact cardinal thresholds.

Correctness: Largely correct that many deontic/lexical/incomparability views violate VNM axioms and that independence is contentious under moral uncertainty, so the machinery won’t apply broadly. Likely overstated/partly incorrect to imply the authors don’t already flag the restriction or that their entire argument becomes “undefined” (they can still argue about narrowness qualitatively, or treat lexical constraints as making the target even narrower). Also the critique conflates intra-theory VNM independence with intertheoretic aggregation issues; the essay’s VNM assumption is about a single view over prospects, not primarily about moral uncertainty.

Clarity: The objection is understandable and points to a specific failure mode (non-VNM moral views make the 0.5/0.9 framework inapplicable), though some terms (“notorious for violating independence under moral uncertainty”) are a bit compressed.

Dead weight: Low; most sentences support the same point, though a few rhetorical flourishes (“window-dressing,” “broad authority … just false”) add little.

Single issue: Yes—focused on the VNM/cardinalization/thresholding applicability.

Overall: Moderate-to-weak critique. It highlights a genuine scope limitation and an overgeneralization risk, but doesn’t decisively undercut the broader thesis and somewhat misses that the essay already partially anticipates the limitation.
title: Lexical constraints and incomparabilities break the cardinal utility framework
